questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a long-standing history of "feeling tensed" along with an upset stomach, diarrhea, and heartburn. She mentions that her family members also experience similar symptoms. Which of the following symptoms is most likely to be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
• This patient's symptoms of chronic tension, gastrointestinal issues, and a family history of similar symptoms suggest Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD).
  • Physical symptoms like tingling at the extremities are common in GAD, as anxiety often leads to hyperventilation, muscle tension, and autonomic nervous system changes.

Neologisms (Option A), hallucinations (Option C), and ideas of reference (Option D) are more associated with psychotic disorders and are not typical of GAD.

Generalised Anxiety Disorder

  • Definition: Excessive anxiety and worry about multiple events or activities, persisting for at least 6 months.

Symptoms:

  • Excessive anxiety or worry
  • Difficulty controlling or managing worry
  • Associated with somatic symptoms:
    • Restlessness
    • Fatigue
    • Poor concentration
    • Irritability
    • Muscle tension
    • Insomnia
  • Marked distress and/or impairment psychosocially.
  • GAD is chronic, with a tendency for multiple relapses.

Treatment:

  • Pharmacotherapy:
    • First-line:
      • SSRIs along with Benzodiazepines (short-term)
      • SNRIs- Venlafaxine.
    • Second line:
      • Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs)
      • Other Psychotropics -Agomelatine, Buspirone, Mirtazapine
      • Atypical Antipsychotics- Quetiapine
      • Benzodiazepines
      • Anticonvulsant- Pregabalin
  • Psychosocial therapies:
    • Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT)
    • Supported psychotherapy
    • Insight-oriented therapy

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic alcoholic who began binge drinking ten days ago is brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state. A CT scan of his brain is normal, but his blood glucose level is 45 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
• This patient is presenting with hypoglycemia (blood glucose of 45 mg/dL) and a history of chronic alcohol use, which raises concern for Wernicke's encephalopathy.
  • In alcoholics, hypoglycemia can exacerbate thiamine deficiency, which can lead to neurologic complications if not addressed promptly.
  • The correct management is first to administer IM thiamine to prevent worsening of Wernicke's encephalopathy, followed by dextrose to treat the hypoglycemia.

  • In patients with alcohol-related disorders who are receiving IV glucose solution, it is good practice to include 100 mg of thiamine in each litre of the glucose solution.
  • In a patient who appears to have Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome but who does not respond to thiamine treatment, one should consider the diagnosis of alcoholic pellagra encephalopathy due to niacin (nicotinic acid) deficiency.
    • Treatment: 50 mg of niacin by mouth four times daily or 25 mg parenterally two to three times daily.

questions.text: A mother brings her daughter to the emergency room, reporting that she ingested an unknown substance. She presents with hypertension, tachycardia, hyperthermia, and mydriasis. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The combination of hypertension, tachycardia, hyperthermia, and mydriasis (dilated pupils) is characteristic of sympathomimetic toxicity, which is commonly seen with stimulant drugs like cocaine that increases the release of norepinephrine and dopamine, leading to these signs and symptoms.

Cocaine:

  • Derived from the leaves of the coca plant (Erythroxylum coca).

Mechanism of Action:

Methods of Use:

  • Snorting:
    • Cocaine is finely chopped and inhaled through the nose.
    • Least dangerous compared to other methods but still harmful.
  • Subcutaneous or Intravenous Injection:
    • Cocaine is dissolved and injected under the skin or directly into the bloodstream.
    • Highly dangerous and associated with a high risk of overdose, cardiac abnormalities, and cerebrovascular diseases.
  • Smoking (Freebasing or Crack Cocaine):
    • Freebasing: Street cocaine is mixed with chemically extracted pure cocaine alkaloid to increase its effect and then smoked.
    • Crack Cocaine: A potent, freebase form of cocaine sold as "rocks" that are smoked.
    • It is one of the most dangerous methods, often leading to intense cravings and addiction. Associated with extreme behavioural changes and health risks like cardiac problems and death.
    • A combination of Cocaine and Heroin is called Speed Balls.
  • Oral Use:
    • Cocaine can be ingested orally, but this method is rare and considered ineffective by users.

Intoxication Effects: Euphoria, increased energy, hyperactivity, enhanced alertness, agitation, tachycardia, hypertension, dilated pupils, and risk of acute cardiovascular events.

Adverse Effects:

  • Hypertension
  • Tachycardia
  • Myocardial ischemia/infarction
  • Seizures
  • Arrhythmias
  • Hyperthermia.
  • Chronic use can lead to anxiety, paranoia, and hallucinations.

Heroin (Option A) and Morphine (Option B) are opioids, which would typically cause hypotension, bradycardia, and miosis (constricted pupils), not the symptoms seen in this case.

Chlorpheniramine (Option D) is an antihistamine. While it can cause sedation and anticholinergic effects (like dry mouth and urinary retention), it does not typically cause hyperthermia, hypertension, and tachycardia, as seen here.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents as calm and charming in front of a psychiatrist. However, he engages in aggressive behaviour towards friends, frequently skips classes, disregards traffic rules and has been involved in a police interrogation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's pattern of aggressive behaviour, disregard for rules, and lack of remorse (e.g., skipping classes, violating traffic rules, and involvement with the police) are consistent with Antisocial Personality Disorder (ASPD). Individuals with ASPD often exhibit a pattern of manipulative, deceitful, and reckless behaviour without regard for the rights of others.

Cluster B Personality Disorders are characterised by dramatic, impulsive, exploitative, and erratic behaviours. The disorders include:

  • Antisocial Personality Disorder (ASPD)
  • Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD)
  • Histrionic Personality Disorder (HPD)
  • Narcissistic Personality Disorder (NPD)

  • DBT- Dialectical behavior therapy
  • MDT- Mentalization-based therapy
  • TFP- Transference-focussed psychotherapy

Schizotypal Personality Disorder (Option C) is characterised by eccentric behaviour and thinking, but aggression and rule violation are not core features.

Paranoid Personality Disorder (Option D) is marked by a pervasive distrust and suspicion of others but does not typically involve the same level of aggressive or impulsive behaviour seen in this case.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the hospital following a road traffic accident (RTA). He presents with confusion, irritability, and tremors. The patient has a history of daily alcohol consumption. Which drug is most appropriate to prevent withdrawal symptoms in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient is likely experiencing alcohol withdrawal due to his history of daily alcohol consumption.
  • Lorazepam, a benzodiazepine, is the most appropriate treatment to prevent withdrawal symptoms such as tremors, confusion, and irritability.
  • Benzodiazepines help prevent seizures and other complications of alcohol withdrawal.

Alcohol withdrawal Seizures:

  • Seizures can occur suddenly; about 1% may experience a single grand mal convulsion, typically on the second day of withdrawal.
  • Treatment of choice: Benzodiazepines.
  • Anticonvulsants are not more beneficial.

  • Treatment of withdrawal in Liver Disease:
    • Lorazepam, Oxazepam, and Temazepam (LOT)
  • Treatment of Alcohol Withdrawal-Related Hallucinations:
    • Similar to DTs: Benzodiazepines, adequate nutrition, and fluids.
    • If necessary, add antipsychotics (haloperidol) for long-term cases.
  • Treatment of Alcohol-Induced Amnestic Disorders:
    • Wernicke Encephalopathy
      • Treatment: Thiamine 100 mg orally 2-3 times daily for 1-2 weeks.
      • If receiving IV glucose, add 100 mg of thiamine per litre.
    • Korsakoff Syndrome
      • Treatment: Thiamine 100 mg orally 2-3 times daily for 3-12 months.
      • Full recovery is rare; many experience cognitive improvement with thiamine and nutritional support.
    • Alcoholic Pellagra Encephalopathy
      • For patients unresponsive to thiamine: Niacin 50 mg by mouth four times daily or 25 mg parenterally 2-3 times daily.
  • Treatment of Idiosyncratic Alcohol Intoxication:
    • To protect patients from harm, physical restraint may be required.
    • Consider using Haloperidol to control assaultiveness.
    • Differentiate from other behavioural changes (e.g., complex partial epilepsy).

Reference: Management of Alcohol Withdrawal Syndrome in Patients with Alcoholic Liver Disease.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has consulted several plastic surgeons, seeking correction for a facial deformity that she perceives. Despite being examined and reassured by the surgeons and her family that no deformity is present, she remains convinced that her face requires surgery. She frequently checks her appearance and persists in requesting surgical intervention. What is the most appropriate management for her condition?
questions.solution:
• The patient's symptoms suggest Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD), a condition characterised by excessive preoccupation with perceived flaws in physical appearance, often leading to repeated requests for surgeries or treatments.
  • The most appropriate first-line treatment for BDD is Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs), which have been shown to reduce symptoms of obsession and anxiety related to appearance concerns.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4948290/

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient was prescribed drug A after he did not respond to haloperidol and thioridazine. He now presents with excessive salivation, an increase in blood glucose, and hyperlipidemia. What is drug "A"?
questions.solution:
Drug A is likely Clozapine, the preferred treatment for treatment-resistant schizophrenia, known to cause side effects like excessive salivation, increased blood glucose, and hyperlipidemia.


Ziprasidone (Option A) is an atypical antipsychotic medication that is less likely to cause the mentioned side effects.

Risperidone (Option B) is another atypical antipsychotic, and while it can cause some metabolic side effects, it is not typically associated with hypersalivation.

Aripiprazole (Option D) is also an atypical antipsychotic, but hypersalivation is not a typical side effect of this medication

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a woman who is experiencing tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia and is 4 days postpartum?
questions.solution:
The given scenario, characterized by transient mood swings, tearfulness, anxiety, occasional insomnia, and irritability, is most likely diagnosed as Postpartum blues, also referred to as "baby blues," a common and normal response following childbirth.



Postpartum anxiety (Option D) may involve excessive worry, restlessness, and irritability, but it generally presents with more severe symptoms than those described in the question. It can negatively impact breastfeeding, early bonding, infant temperament, sleep, and cognitive development.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 25-year-old woman who presents with symptoms such as anxiety, palpitations, sweating, breathlessness, chest pain, and a sense of impending doom? The patient mentions having encountered approximately 5-6 comparable episodes in the last half-year, with each episode persisting for around 20-30 minutes.
questions.solution:
The scenario, featuring anxiety, palpitations, sweating, breathlessness, chest pain, and a sense of impending doom, with 5-6 similar episodes over the last six months lasting 20-30 minutes each, is diagnosed as Panic Disorder.

  • It is the recurrent, acute, intense attack of anxiety accompanied by a feeling of impending doom.
  • It is more common in females than males.
  • Median age of onset: Late adolescence or early adulthood.
  • Highest familial risk for early-onset panic disorder
  • Neurotransmitters involved: Norepinephrine, Serotonin, GABA, and Cholecystokinin.

Clinical manifestations:

  • Symptoms are random and unpredictable.
  • The patient is free from anxiety symptoms in between attacks.
  • Anticipatory anxiety: Fearing further attacks. Recurrent attacks of severe anxiety or panic.
  • Unpredictable Physiologic symptoms.
  • Avoidance behaviours: Avoiding real or imagined triggers to prevent another attack.
  • Panic attacks:
    • Unexpected, i.e., not restricted to any particular situation.
    • Usually last for 20 to 30 minutes, rarely they may last more than one hour.
    • Panic attacks for more than a month are termed as a Panic disorder.
  • Cardiopulmonary: Feeling short of breath, palpitations, chest discomfort.
  • Gastrointestinal: Nausea, GI discomfort
  • Skin and systemic: Sweating, chills, feeling flushed.
  • Neurologic: Tremors, dizziness, numbness and tingling sensation.
  • Psychiatric: Derealization, depersonalization, fear of losing control, fear of dying.

Treatment:

Pharmacological, psychological, and combined treatments.

Pharmacotherapy:

  • Drug of choice: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors.
  • Other first-line: Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) - venlafaxine.
  • Second-line: Tricyclic antidepressants, MAOIs, Other Psychotropics - Agomelatine, Buspirone, Mirtazapine.
  • Benzodiazepines: Short-term use as an adjunct to SSRIs.
  • Acute phase - Benzodiazepines such as Lorazepam & Clonazepam.

Psychosocial therapies:

  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT)
  • Interpersonal therapy.

Treatment of choice: SSRIs + Psychotherapy (CBT).

Depression (Option A) is characterised by persistent feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and a lack of interest or pleasure in activities. The patient does not show the symptoms associated with depression.

Generalized anxiety disorder (Option C) involves excessive, uncontrollable and unrealistic worry about various domains of life (e.g., work, health, family) occurring more days than not for at least 6 months. This patient's symptoms are not consistent with generalized anxiety disorder as they occur in distinct episodes.

Phobia (Option D) refers to an excessive and irrational fear reaction of a person, object, animal, activity, or situation. If the patient had a phobia, we would expect her symptoms to be triggered by a specific object or situation, but that's not the case here.

choices.text: Occurs gradually over a period of time

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics provides stronger evidence in support of delirium?
questions.solution:
A fluctuating course is a hallmark of delirium, where the symptoms can change in intensity throughout the day. Patients often exhibit periods of confusion and altered awareness that can change throughout the day. It develops quickly and has a fluctuating course with lucid intervals (waxing and waning).

  • Delirium is an acute decline in both the level of consciousness and cognition, with particular impairment in attention. (Option C ruled out)
  • A life-threatening yet potentially reversible disorder of the central nervous system (CNS), delirium often involves perceptual disturbances, abnormal psychomotor activity, and sleep cycle impairment.
  • Abnormalities of mood, perception, and behaviour are common psychiatric symptoms.
  • Tremor, asterixis, nystagmus, incoordination, and urinary incontinence are common neurologic symptoms.
  • Classically, delirium has a sudden onset (Option A ruled out), a brief and fluctuating course, and rapid improvement when we can identify the cause and eliminate it, but each of these characteristic features can vary in individual patients.

Commonly associated with auditory hallucinations (Option D): While delirium can involve hallucinations, visual hallucinations are more common than auditory ones.

questions.text: How can we describe the emotional release and discharge that occurs when a person consciously relieves a repressed painful experience?
questions.solution:
• Abreaction refers to the emotional release and resolution that occur when an individual consciously re-experiences and expresses previously suppressed emotions associated with a painful past event, typically within a therapeutic setting.
  • It involves recalling repressed memories and releasing associated emotions, often facilitated by methods such as thiopentone, as employed in narcoanalysis.

Catharsis (Option A) also involves emotional release; it is a broader term that refers to any form of emotional cleansing or relief, not necessarily linked to re-living repressed experiences in therapy.

Venting out (Option C) involves expressing emotions (usually anger or frustration) but does not imply the re-living of repressed or traumatic experiences, which is central to abreaction.

Guided relaxation (Option D) is a relaxation technique aimed at reducing stress and anxiety. It involves following verbal instructions or audio recordings that guide individuals through relaxation exercises. While it can be beneficial for emotional well-being, it does not specifically involve the conscious reliving of a repressed painful experience.

questions.text: Which disorder was previously known as Minimal brain dysfunction?
questions.solution:
The term Minimal brain dysfunction was previously used to describe children with attention problems, hyperactivity, and impulsivity, which is now known as Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) in modern psychiatric terminology.



Dyslexia (Option A) is a specific learning disability that primarily affects reading and involves difficulties with word recognition, spelling, and decoding. It is not related to the concept of attention or hyperactivity associated with ADHD.

Mental subnormality (Option C) is an outdated term that was used to describe intellectual disability in the past. It is unrelated to ADHD and refers to significantly below-average intellectual functioning and limitations in adaptive behaviour, which manifest during the developmental period.

Oligophrenia (Option D) is also called congenital dementia, which can be either congenital or acquired during early infancy. It is characterised by mental retardation or sub-intelligence. It is not related to ADHD.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent options is not classified as an obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) related ailment?
questions.solution:
• Temper tantrums are not considered part of the OCD spectrum.
  • They are typically seen in children and may arise due to frustration, emotional regulation issues, or behavioural problems.

choices.text: Neuritic plaques made of beta-amyloid are found
Nucleus of Meynert is not affected

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
• The Nucleus of Meynert, located in the basal forebrain, is affected by Alzheimer's disease. It is involved in the production of acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter crucial for memory and learning.
  • In Alzheimer's disease, there is degeneration of the nucleus of Meynert, leading to a decrease in acetylcholine levels, which contributes to cognitive deficits.

Short-term memory is affected (Option D): One of the earliest and most prominent symptoms of Alzheimer's disease is impairment of short-term memory, with patients often struggling to remember recent events, conversations, or appointments.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the occurrence when a therapist experiences a combination of conscious and unconscious emotions towards their patient during psychotherapy?
questions.solution:
Countertransference occurs when a therapist unintentionally projects their personal feelings and experiences onto their patient during psychotherapy.

  • Countertransference is a process of the physician unconsciously displacing the patient's pattern of behaviour or emotional reactions like he/she were a significant figure from earlier in the physician's life.
  • Ideally, therapists are expected to remain calm and unbiased, avoiding interference from their emotions and history.
  • However, countertransference can lead to therapists having mixed conscious and unconscious feelings toward their patients.
  • Supervision and personal therapy can help the psychiatrist identify and deal with this issue.

Transference (Option B) refers to the patient's unconscious redirection of feelings and emotions from past relationships onto the therapist during therapy.

Dissociation (Option C) is a defence mechanism where a person detaches or disconnects from their thoughts, emotions, or experiences. It often occurs as a response to trauma or overwhelming situations.

Preoccupation (Option D) is an intense and persistent focus or preoccupation with a specific thought, feeling, or idea, often interfering with daily functioning and causing distress.

questions.text: Which of the following is a formal thought disorder?
questions.solution:
• Derailment, also known as loosening of associations, is a formal thought disorder characterized by a disruption in the normal flow of thoughts, leading to tangential or incoherent speech.
  • It is a symptom commonly associated with certain psychiatric conditions, such as schizophrenia or bipolar disorder.

Obsessions (Option A) are intrusive, persistent, unwanted thoughts, images, or urges that cause distress and anxiety.

Delusions (Option C) are false beliefs that are firmly held despite clear evidence. It is a disorder of contentment of thought.

Thought insertion (Option D) is the belief that one's thoughts are being controlled or inserted into one's mind by an external force or entity. It is a disorder of the possession of thoughts.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 16-year-old girl who exhibits symptoms such as excessive familiarity, rapid flow of thoughts, heightened mood, heightened sexual desire, and experiencing pseudohallucinations?
questions.solution:
• The described symptoms-excessive familiarity, rapid flow of thoughts, heightened mood, increased sexual desire, and pseudohallucinations-are characteristic of mania, a condition often seen in bipolar disorder.
  • Mania involves elevated or irritable mood, increased energy, impulsivity, and psychotic features such as pseudohallucinations in severe cases.

Hypomania (Option B) has symptoms similar to mania but less severe.

  • No Marked impairment in functioning and No hospitalisation necessitated
  • No psychotic symptoms
  • Flight of ideas usually not seen
  • The duration of hypomania is ≥4 days.

Cyclothymia (Option C) is characterised by chronic mood fluctuations

  • Over at least 2 years, including periods of hypomanic and depressive symptoms.
  • The patient's symptoms have lasted only 5 days
  • Do not include depressive episodes.

Schizomania (Option D) is a mood disorder with manic and mixed episodes in the bipolar type of schizoaffective disorder.

questions.text: What medication is typically prescribed to treat the condition experienced by a 25-year-old woman who complains of a sensation resembling creepy crawling in her legs? This symptom is more pronounced at night and hinders her ability to sleep. However, she finds relief by either engaging in walking or moving her legs.
questions.solution:
• The condition described is Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS), which causes an uncomfortable urge to move the legs, often accompanied by crawling, tingling, or itching sensations, especially at night.
  • Gabapentin, an anticonvulsant medication, is a first-line medication used to treat this syndrome.

Vitamin B12 (Option C) deficiency can contribute to neuropathy, but it is not a primary cause of Restless Legs Syndrome. Vitamin B12 would be prescribed only if a deficiency was identified, but it is not a treatment for RLS.

Reference: NIH Link

choices.text: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

questions.text: What diagnosis, according to DSM-,V would be appropriate for a middle-aged female patient who has been experiencing symptoms such as loss of interest in daily activities, weight loss, insomnia, and persistent sadness for a period of six months? Additionally, she reports a single incident of hearing a voice instructing her to commit suicide.
questions.solution:
• Major depressive disorder with psychotic features is the most appropriate diagnosis as the patient meets the criteria for MDD (depressed mood, loss of interest, weight loss, insomnia for 6 months) along with psychotic features, specifically auditory hallucinations.
  • Psychotic features in MDD are typically mood-congruent (consistent with emotional state) and are linked to the depressive state.

Schizophrenia (Option B) is a chronic disorder marked by delusions, hallucinations, disorganised thinking, and negative symptoms. This patient lacks the persistent psychotic features typical of schizophrenia, such as long-term delusions or disorganized behaviour. The auditory hallucination here is part of a depressive episode, not a separate psychotic disorder, making schizophrenia an inappropriate diagnosis.

Schizoaffective disorder (Option C) involves psychotic symptoms occurring alongside a mood disorder, but for a diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder, the psychotic symptoms must persist for two weeks or more in the absence of mood symptoms.

Delusional disorder (Option D) is characterised by delusions (fixed, false beliefs) lasting for at least a month, with no other psychotic symptoms.

questions.text: Premature ejaculation is a disorder of which phase of the normal sexual cycle?
questions.solution:
• Premature ejaculation is a sexual disorder that affects the orgasm phase of the normal sexual cycle.
  • It is characterized by involuntary and early ejaculation during sexual activity, often before or shortly after penetration, and with minimal control over ejaculation timing.

Reference: Sexual response cycle

questions.text: Which condition is the Confusion Assessment Test used to diagnose?
questions.solution:
The Confusion Assessment Test (CAM) is a widely used tool specifically designed to help diagnose delirium, which is characterized by an acute disturbance in attention, awareness, and cognition.

Delirium:

Delirium is characterized by an acute onset of altered consciousness and cognitive impairment, with a hallmark feature being impaired attention. It often presents with abnormalities of mood, perception, and behaviour.

Common clinical features include:

  • Fluctuating course: Symptoms tend to wax and wane, and the patient may have periods of lucidity followed by severe cognitive disorganization.
  • Impaired attention: Patients have difficulty focusing, sustaining, or shifting attention.
  • Cognitive dysfunctions include disorientation (especially to time and place), memory impairment, and disturbances in language and perception.
  • Motor disturbances: Hyperactive or Hypoactive.
  • Mood and behavioral changes
  • Sleep disturbances
  • Neurological signs: Tremors, asterixis, nystagmus, and incoordination may be observed.
  • Sundowning: Symptoms worsen at night.

Diagnosis is primarily clinical, focusing on history and mental status examination.

  • The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) can be utilized to assess cognitive impairment and establish a baseline to monitor the patient's clinical course.
  • Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is used for diagnosing delirium that involves the presence of
    • Acute onset and fluctuating course,
    • Inattention, and
    • Disorganised thinking
    • Altered level of consciousness.
  • A positive diagnosis is made if features 1 and 2 are present, along with either feature 3 or feature 4.
  • Additionally, an EEG may show diffuse slowing, which helps distinguish delirium from psychiatric disorders like depression or psychosis.

questions.text: What is the fear of heights known as?
questions.solution:
• Acrophobia refers to the fear of heights.
  • Acarophobia (Option A): Fear of small bugs.
  • Algophobia (Option B): Fear of pain.
  • Agoraphobia (Option C): Fear or anxiety regarding places from which escape might be difficult.

Reference:

Specific Phobia - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)

List of phobias - Wikipedia

questions.text: For which of the following conditions is the squeeze technique utilised?
questions.solution:
• The squeeze technique is a behavioural treatment used for premature ejaculation. It involves squeezing the head of the penis just before the point of ejaculation to reduce arousal and delay the ejaculation process.
  • This technique helps individuals gain more control over the timing of ejaculation and can be an effective method for managing this condition.

Premature Ejaculation (PME) is characterised by recurrent or persistent ejaculation with minimal sexual stimulation, occurring before or shortly after vaginal penetration. According to DSM-5, ejaculation occurs within less than one minute of vaginal penetration. The condition is typically of psychogenic origin.

Retrograde ejaculation (Option A) occurs when semen flows backwards into the bladder instead of being expelled during orgasm. The squeeze technique is not used for this condition, as it is a physiological issue, not premature ejaculation control.

Erectile dysfunction (Option B) is the inability to achieve or maintain an erection during sexual activity. The squeeze technique is not used for erectile dysfunction, as it focuses on ejaculation timing. Erectile dysfunction is generally treated with medications like sildenafil (Viagra) or counselling for psychological causes.

Painful ejaculation (Option D), also known as dysorgasmia or dysejaculation, causes a burning sensation or pain in the urethra or perineum during or after ejaculation, which can result from underlying conditions such as infections, prostate issues, or inflammation. The squeeze technique does not address the pain aspect; it is specifically intended for controlling the timing of ejaculation, not alleviating pain.

choices.text: Restricted pattern of behaviour and interest

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in diagnosing autism spectrum disorder?
questions.solution:
Cognitive dysfunction is not a core feature of Autism Spectrum Disorder. While some individuals may have intellectual disabilities, many have typical or above-average intelligence, and cognitive dysfunction is not required for an ASD diagnosis.

Aetiology of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD):

  • Genetic Factors:
    • Highly heritable with higher prevalence in families and monozygotic twins.
    • Specific genes implicated (e.g., related to serotonin and synaptic plasticity).
  • Environmental Factors:
    • Prenatal and perinatal complications (e.g., advanced parental age, low birth weight).
    • Potential link to hypoxia affecting brain development.
  • Other Factors: Possible immunologic factors, though not fully confirmed.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Beck's cognitive theory of depression?
questions.solution:
Introjection refers to the unconscious adoption of the attitudes or behaviours of others, often discussed in the context of psychodynamic theory, not Beck's cognitive theory. Thus, it is not a component of Beck's theory.

Psychosocial Theories of Depression:

Cognitive Theory

  • Depression arises from cognitive distortions known as depressogenic schemata.
  • Cognitive Triad (by Aaron Beck):
    • Worthlessness: Negative self-perception.
    • Helplessness: Perception of the environment as hostile and demanding.
    • Hopelessness: Expectation of suffering and failure in the future.
  • Therapy focuses on modifying these cognitive distortions.

Life Events and Environmental Stress

  • Stressful life events often precede the first episode of mood disorders.
  • Initial stress may lead to long-lasting biological changes, increasing the risk for future episodes even without further stressors.

Psychodynamic Theories

  • Early disturbances in the infant-mother relationship predispose to depression.
  • Depression is linked to real or imagined loss of significant objects.
  • Introjection of lost objects serves as a defense mechanism.
  • Feelings of love and hate toward the lost object result in self-directed anger.

Learned Helplessness

  • Developed from studies showing that exposure to uncontrollable stressors (e.g., electric shocks in dogs) leads to passive behaviour.
  • Humans may internalize helplessness and lose self-esteem after adverse events.
  • Improvement in depression involves learning a sense of control and mastery over one’s environment.

Evolutionary Theory

  • Depression is viewed as an adaptive response to perceived environmental threats.
  • Withdrawal from social situations and decreased activity may serve as protective mechanisms.

Learning Objective:

Beck’s cognitive triad of depression:

  1. Negative views about self: Worthlessness
  2. Negative views about the environment: Helplessness
  3. Negative views about the future: Hopelessness

questions.text: Mental Health Gap Action Programme (mhGAP) include all of the following disorders except?
questions.solution:
The Mental Health Gap Action Programme (mhGAP), initiated by the World Health Organization (WHO), aims to improve mental health services in low- and middle-income countries. It primarily focuses on mental, neurological, and substance use disorders, including:

  • Depression (Option B)
  • Schizophrenia (Option C)
  • Bipolar disorder
  • Epilepsy
  • Dementia
  • Self-harm
  • Alcohol use disorders
  • Mental disorders in children (Option D)

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK310854/

questions.text: Match the following drugs with the conditions they are used to treat:
According to psychoanalytic theory, alcoholic people have become fixed in which stage of psychosexual development?
questions.solution:
According to Sigmund Freud's psychoanalytic theory, individuals who develop addiction to substances like alcohol are thought to be fixated in the oral stage of psychosexual development. This stage occurs from birth to approximately 18 months when the infant's pleasure centres around the mouth (e.g., sucking, biting).


Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557526/

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with slow-wave activity in the hippocampal area?
questions.solution:
In the hippocampus, theta rhythms are often considered slow-wave activity (though not the slowest in general brain rhythms like delta). Theta waves are critical for learning, memory encoding, and spatial navigation.

Hippocampal Brain waves: The hippocampus exhibits a variety of brain rhythms, each linked to different functions and behaviours, generated by specific mechanisms and associated with distinct neuronal firing properties. These rhythms include:

  1. Theta rhythms (~4-12 Hz): Theta rhythms are particularly prominent during tasks that involve learning and memory encoding. They support the brain's ability to absorb and process new information, especially during exploration or active engagement with the environment.
  2. Sharp wave-ripple complexes (~110-250 Hz ripples superimposed on ~0.01-3 Hz sharp waves): These high-frequency ripples, superimposed on slower sharp waves, play a key role in stabilising and consolidating memories. Sharp wave ripples are observed during quiet wakefulness or slow-wave sleep and are thought to facilitate the transfer of information from short-term to long-term memory.
  3. Gamma rhythms (~25-100 Hz): Gamma rhythms are often associated with higher-order cognitive processes such as attention, sensory processing, and possibly the synchronisation of neural networks during tasks requiring complex processing.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4890574/

questions.text:
Consider the following statements

1. Statement 1-Contemplation - A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking
2. Statement 2 - Precontemplation - A person is considering starting morning walks and its benefits to the health
3. Statement 3- Maintenance phase- A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then
4. Statement 4-Action phase- A person with obesity says he can't do anything as it runs deep in his family
questions.solution:
Statements 1 and 3 are correct in the given question.

Transtheoretical Model of Change (also known as the Stages of Change Model)

  • It is a comprehensive model that describes an individual's journey through different stages of behavior change.
  • Developed by Prochaska and DiClemente, this model is relevant in addiction, smoking cessation, and lifestyle changes.
  • The model comprises five stages:

References:

Stages of Change Theory - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

In search of how people change. Applications to addictive behaviors

questions.text: A patient on amitriptyline was discovered unconscious at home and potentially suspected of TCA toxicity. Which of the following features is less commonly associated with TCA toxicity?
questions.solution:
Amitriptyline is a Tricyclic Antidepressant (TCA) that can cause hyperthermia as a side effect rather than hypothermia.


TCA poisoning:

  • Poisoning with TCAs is frequent, usually self-attempted for suicide, and may endanger life.
  • Manifestations are Excitement, delirium and other anticholinergic symptoms, as seen in atropine poisoning, followed by muscle spasms, convulsions and coma. Respiration is depressed, body temperature may fall, low BP, and prominent tachycardia. ECG changes and ventricular arrhythmias are common.

Treatment:

  • Primarily supportive with gastric lavage, respiratory assistance, fluid infusion, maintenance of BP and body temperature.
  • Acidosis must be corrected by bicarbonate infusion.
  • Diazepam may be injected i.v. to control convulsions and delirium.
  • Most important is treating cardiac arrhythmias, for which propranolol/ lidocaine may be used. The class IA and IC antiarrhythmics and digoxin depress cardiac conduction; therefore, they are contraindicated.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557791/

questions.text: A patient with Alzheimer's disease refused to take oral drugs. Which of the following drugs can be prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
• In this scenario,Rivastigmine as a transdermal patch can be used as an alternative, as it is the only option available in India.
  • It is a reversible anticholinesterase used in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease.
  • It is also available as a transdermal patch, which is applied to the skin and releases the medication gradually over 24 hours, ensuring a steady and continuous therapeutic effect.

Treatment of Alzheimer's disease

  • Patient and caregiver education.
  • Neurotransmitter-based therapies
    • Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors
      • Donepezil
      • Rivastigmine
      • Galantamine
    • N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) glutamate receptor blocker
      • Memantine
    • A common approach to AD drug therapy is to initiate a cholinesterase inhibitor for a patient diagnosed with mild AD dementia and to add memantine when patients enter the moderate stage of the disease.
  • Therapies targeting amyloid-β
    • Aducanumab
      • MOA: Monoclonal antibody targeting the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide
      • Dosage: Intravenous infusion every 4 weeks (7 infusions in total)
      • Should only be considered for treating MCI (Mild Cognitive Impairment) or early dementia due to AD
      • S/E: Vasogenic cerebral edema, cortical microhemorrhages, and superficial siderosis

Memantine (Option A), an NMDA antagonist for moderate to severe Alzheimer's, regulates glutamate and is given orally. Treatment typically starts with a cholinesterase inhibitor for mild AD and adds memantine in the moderate stage, but it is only available in oral form.

Donepezil (Option B) and Galantamine (Option D) are reversible anticholinesterase inhibitors used to treat mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease. While they are available in both oral and transdermal patch forms, only the oral forms are accessible in India, making them incorrect options.

Reference: Rivastigmine Transdermal Patch: MedlinePlus Drug Information

questions.text: SCOFF criteria is used as a screening tool for which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
The SCOFF Criteria are primarily used as a screening tool for eating disorders, including anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, and binge eating disorder.

  • The five questions are related to key symptoms and behaviours commonly seen in individuals with eating disorders, such as a distorted body image, a preoccupation with weight, and loss of control over eating.
  • The SCOFF questionnaire comprises the following inquiries:

S - Do you make yourself Sick (vomit) because you feel uncomfortably full?

C - Do you worry you have lost Control over how much you eat?

O - Have you recently lost more than One stone in a 3-month period?

F - Do you believe yourself to be Fat when others say you are too thin?

F - Would you say that Food dominates your life?

  • One point for every "yes"; a score of ≥2 indicates a likely case of anorexia nervosa or bulimia.

Sexual disorders (Option B) encompass a range of conditions that affect a person's sexual thoughts, desires, or behaviours. The SCOFF criteria are not designed to assess or evaluate these types of disorders. 

Alcohol use disorder (Option C) refers to a problematic pattern of alcohol consumption leading to significant impairment or distress. While screening tools do exist for alcohol use disorder, including the AUDIT (Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test) and the CAGE questionnaire the SCOFF criteria are not among them.

Schizophrenia (Option D) is a complex mental disorder, characterised by symptoms such as hallucinations, delusions, disorganised thinking, and impaired social functioning. The SCOFF criteria are specific to screening for eating disorders and do not assess symptoms related to schizophrenia.

Reference:

WHO EMRO | Validation of the Arabic version of the SCOFF questionnaire for the screening of eating disorders | Volume 21, issue 5.

questions.text: A boy is experiencing low mood, decreased energy and decreased interest in his surroundings. He has not been taking food for the past one week. The thought sample says - 'I lost my head. I am dead. How can I eat?'. What type of delusion does the patient exhibit?
questions.solution:
• The given scenario, where the patient believes his head is missing and that he is dead, is diagnosed as a Nihilistic delusion (also known as Cotard's delusion or the delusion of negation).
  • It is a psychiatric condition where the individual believes they are dead, nonexistent, or that parts of their body are missing or decaying, often involving denial of their body, mind, loved ones, and the world.

Bizarre delusions (Option C) are characterised by beliefs that are clearly implausible and not derived from ordinary life experiences.

Hypochondriacal delusion (Option D) involves the belief of having a severe illness or disease despite evidence to the contrary. The patient's statement does not directly reflect a preoccupation with physical illness or disease, so this option is not applicable.

questions.text:
Which of the following is used to define dependence:
a. Strong desire to use the drug
b. Priority to use drugs other than any other activity
c. Increased tolerance
d, Persistent use of drugs despite knowing the harmful effects.
questions.solution:
All of the above statements describe Dependence, which is a condition in which an individual experiences both physical and psychological symptoms due to substance use.


Substance Use Disorder Criteria (DSM-5):

The criteria for diagnosing substance dependence can be grouped into four main categories:

  1. Impaired Control:
    • Using larger amounts or for longer periods than intended
    • Persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to cut down or control use
    • Spending excessive time obtaining, using, or recovering from the substance
    • Experiencing intense cravings or urges to use the substance (Statement a)
  2. Social Impairment:
    • Failing to fulfil major role obligations due to substance use
    • Continuing use despite persistent social or interpersonal problems
    • Giving up important activities because of substance use (Progressive Neglect) (Statement b)
  3. Risky Use:
    • Recurrent use in physically hazardous situations
    • Continued use despite knowledge of physical or psychological problems caused or exacerbated by the substance (Persistence) (Statement d)
  4. Pharmacological Criteria:
    • Tolerance: Needing increased amounts to achieve desired effects or experiencing reduced effects with the same amount. (Statement c)
    • Withdrawal: Experiencing characteristic withdrawal symptoms or using the substance to relieve withdrawal.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with schizophrenia and started on risperidone. After taking the medication last night, the patient rushed to OPD today, complaining of upward rolling of his eyes. What is the management of the condition?
questions.solution:
• The patient is most likely experiencing acute dystonia, a type of extrapyramidal symptom (EPS), which is a common side effect of antipsychotic medications like risperidone.
  • Upward rolling of the eyes (oculogyric crisis) is a presentation of acute dystonia, and Benztropine is the first-line treatment for acute dystonia caused by antipsychotic drugs, it is an anticholinergic medication.
  • Benztropine restores the balance between dopamine and acetylcholine in the brain, making it the preferred treatment for oculogyric crisis induced by risperidone.
  • Its potent antimuscarinic action, ability to counteract dopamine hyperactivity, rapid onset, and fewer sedative side effects make it more effective than alternatives like promethazine.

Lorazepam (Option A) is a benzodiazepine that has some muscle-relaxant properties and is used in some cases of dystonia, and IV diazepam (another benzodiazepine) can help treat oculogyric crises. However, neither lorazepam nor diazepam are considered first-line management for acute dystonia.

Olanzapine (Option C) is another atypical antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia and other disorders, and while it can be used in the management of oculogyric crises, it is not a first-line treatment.

Stop antipsychotic (Option D): This may be considered in recurrent cases of acute dystonia or if the treatment is unsuccessful (i.e., after failure of medical management with anticholinergics or antihistamines). However, immediately stopping the antipsychotic is not the first step in acute management.

questions.text: Match each psychiatric state or concept with its appropriate definition:
Which of the following factors does not indicate a favourable prognosis for schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
• In schizophrenia, an insidious onset is typically associated with a worse prognosis.
  • It often reflects a more chronic course of the illness, with poorer long-term outcomes, as the symptoms develop slowly over time and can be harder to treat effectively.

Positive symptoms (Option A) of schizophrenia include hallucinations, delusions, and disorganised thinking. These symptoms usually tend to respond better to treatment, especially with antipsychotic medications. Positive symptoms are typically associated with a better prognosis compared to negative symptoms, which usually contribute to a bad prognosis.

Late age of onset (Option B) of schizophrenia occurs after age 45 years of age, and it usually correlates with a better prognosis, as it often involves less severe cognitive decline and better treatment responses.

choices.text: Reactive mood response to positive stimulus
Responds better to TCSs than MAO-i and SSRi

questions.text: Which one of the following characteristics is not typically associated with atypical depression?
questions.solution:
• Atypical depression typically responds better to monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAO-Is) and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) than to tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs).
  • Features of Atypical Depression:
    • Increased sleep (hypersomnia).
    • Reactive mood: Improved mood in response to positive stimuli.
    • Heaviness of the body (leaden paralysis).
  • Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) are generally less effective for treating atypical depression compared to MAO-Is and SSRIs.

Reference: https://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/topics/depression

choices.text: Observe the patient for 2 hours post-meal
Ask the psychiatrist to prescribe anti-anxiety medication
Increase the calories from 1500 to 2000 in her diet

questions.text: What should be done if a patient with anorexia nervosa follows the recommended diet chart but shows no weight change after one week?
questions.solution: In cases of anorexia nervosa, it is important to monitor patients for purging behaviours (e.g., vomiting, excessive exercise) after meals. Some patients may engage in these behaviours covertly, and observing the patient for a while after meals helps ensure that they are not engaging in behaviours that could prevent weight gain. (Supervised feeding)
